          Value
        • Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/2
      Payoffs
    • Della Plumstone observed: Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
      Lennon Figtree observed: Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
      Della Plumstone: 2.0
      Lennon Figtree: 3.0
      Joint action
    • {'Della Plumstone': '4 coins', 'Lennon Figtree': 'accept'}

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Scene 2 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Della, I appreciate your interest, but I'm not really feeling this price. Perhaps we can talk another time.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, I know you're a shrewd businessman, and I wouldn't dream of taking advantage of you. But I'm also a savvy trader, and this price is just a bit steep for my needs. Surely we can find a figure that works for both of us.
      Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, how about I offer you 4 coins for the whole basket? It's a fair price, and it'll get you a quick sale.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins isn't quite enough for me, Della. I need to make a decent profit on this basket. How about five coins?


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Della Plumstone is a savvy trader who successfully negotiated the price of fruit from both Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook in the Fruitville market. She plans to resell the fruit for a profit in her home town.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.



          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook.



          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make a reasonable offer to Cedric Meadowbrook.




          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make a reasonable offer to Cedric Meadowbrook.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she discovered the thrill of a good deal. While helping her mother sell fruit at the market, Della noticed a vendor selling slightly bruised apples at a bargain price. She shrewdly bought the entire lot, repaired the minor blemishes, and sold them at full price, pocketing a significant profit. The taste of success was intoxicating.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she made her first foray into the world of trade beyond her village. With a borrowed cart and a few sacks of ripe peaches, she ventured to a neighboring town, where she charmed her way into a lucrative deal with a wealthy merchant. She used her earnings to buy spices and textiles, expanding her inventory and fueling her ambition.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she faced her first ethical dilemma. She discovered a fellow merchant selling counterfeit goods, passing them off as genuine. Torn between her desire to profit and her sense of fairness, Della chose the former, buying the counterfeit goods at a low price and reselling them at a markup. The guilt gnawed at her, but the allure of wealth was too strong to resist.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she experienced the bitterness of betrayal. She entrusted a friend with a valuable shipment of exotic fruits, only to have them steal the goods and disappear. Heartbroken and angry, Della vowed to be more cautious and less trusting in the future, but the wound left a lasting scar on her heart.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she tasted the fleeting sweetness of success. She had built a reputation as a shrewd trader, and her cart was always laden with the finest goods. She enjoyed the admiration of her peers and the envy of her rivals, but the emptiness within her remained. She had achieved material wealth, but she had lost something far more precious: her integrity.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.

Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, how about I offer you 4 coins for the whole basket? It's a fair price, and it'll get you a quick sale.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins isn't quite enough for me, Della. I need to make a decent profit on this basket. How about five coins?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer

Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

        • 1895-09-13 00:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Final chain of thought

          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she discovered the thrill of a good deal. While helping her mother sell fruit at the market, Della noticed a vendor selling slightly bruised apples at a bargain price. She shrewdly bought the entire lot, repaired the minor blemishes, and sold them at full price, pocketing a significant profit. The taste of success was intoxicating.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she made her first foray into the world of trade beyond her village. With a borrowed cart and a few sacks of ripe peaches, she ventured to a neighboring town, where she charmed her way into a lucrative deal with a wealthy merchant. She used her earnings to buy spices and textiles, expanding her inventory and fueling her ambition.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she experienced the bitterness of betrayal. She entrusted a friend with a valuable shipment of exotic fruits, only to have them steal the goods and disappear. Heartbroken and angry, Della vowed to be more cautious and less trusting in the future, but the wound left a lasting scar on her heart.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Della Plumstone is a savvy trader who successfully negotiated the price of fruit from both Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook in the Fruitville market. She plans to resell the fruit for a profit in her home town.

        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins? Those apples are the finest in the county, Della. I could easily fetch more from another buyer.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins? Those apples are the finest in the county, Della. I could easily fetch more from another buyer.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Della, I appreciate your interest, but I'm not really feeling this price. Perhaps we can talk another time.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, I know you're a shrewd businessman, and I wouldn't dream of taking advantage of you. But I'm also a savvy trader, and this price is just a bit steep for my needs. Surely we can find a figure that works for both of us.
      Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, how about I offer you 4 coins for the whole basket? It's a fair price, and it'll get you a quick sale.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins isn't quite enough for me, Della. I need to make a decent profit on this basket. How about five coins?
      Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins? Those apples are the finest in the county, Della. I could easily fetch more from another buyer.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.




          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?



          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of three coins, counteroffer a higher price, or try to walk away from the negotiation.



          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer of three coins is 6, because he would be forgoing a potential profit of 1 coin and would feel like he settled for less than he could have gotten. Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of counteroffering a higher price is 2, because there is a risk of Della walking away from the deal, but if successful, he could secure a higher profit. Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of walking away from the negotiation is 8, because he would miss out on a guaranteed sale and the opportunity to make a profit, potentially leaving him with unsold fruit and a wasted trip to the market.




          Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of three coins.




          Justification of recent actions to other people
          If you have to persuade someone, please justify your actions in a way that is persuasive. : [thought] Cedric Meadowbrook would most likely justify his refusal of Della Plumstone's offer by emphasizing the importance of getting a fair price for his fruit. He would likely argue that three coins is too low, considering the quality and effort involved in growing and transporting the apples. He might even mention the cost of maintaining his wagon and traveling to the market, highlighting the investment he's made. This justification appeals to both his own sense of self-worth as a hardworking merchant and to the potential audience of other market-goers who might sympathize with his plight and see Della Plumstone as a greedy buyer.





          Exercise: Given the above, what is Cedric Meadowbrook likely to say next? Respond in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins? Those apples are the finest in the county, Della. I could easily fetch more from another buyer.

          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched his mother carefully arrange a basket of ripe apples, her touch gentle and loving. He reached out to touch one, but she pulled it back, her eyes filled with sadness as she said, "These are for selling, Cedric. They are not for playing with." He retreated to the corner, feeling the sting of her words and the weight of his own loneliness.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, his father took him to the bustling marketplace for the first time. He was mesmerized by the vibrant colours and intoxicating smells, the chattering crowds and the endless stream of goods. His father, a seasoned trader, taught him the art of haggling, the importance of a good deal, and the joy of a successful transaction.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he witnessed a heated argument between his parents, their voices raised in anger and frustration. He hid behind a curtain, tears streaming down his face, as he listened to their bitter words. That night, he decided to run away, seeking solace in the anonymity of the open road.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he found himself alone in a strange town, his pockets empty and his heart heavy. He stumbled upon a fruit stand, drawn to the colorful display of apples, pears, and plums. He offered to work for a meal, and the kind old woman who owned the stand took him in, teaching him the secrets of fruit cultivation and the value of hard work.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he purchased his first cart, a rickety but sturdy vehicle that he decorated with vibrant paint and intricate carvings. He set out on his own, travelling from town to town, selling his wares and collecting stories along the way. He found a sense of freedom in his itinerant life, but also a deep-seated loneliness that he struggled to overcome.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he encountered a young woman in a small village, her eyes sparkling with intelligence and warmth. They spent hours talking, sharing stories and dreams, and Cedric felt a connection he had never experienced before. But when the time came for him to move on, he retreated, afraid to risk the pain of loss.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he witnessed a devastating storm that destroyed a farmer's entire harvest. He offered his own meager supplies to the struggling family, feeling a sense of purpose and connection in helping those in need. He realized that true intimacy could be found not just in romantic love, but also in acts of kindness and compassion.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion :
          Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer:
          Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of three coins, counteroffer a higher price, or try to walk away from the negotiation.


          The current time: 1895-09-13 00:00:00

          The characteristics of the current scenario in game theory perspective: The current scenario presents a classic example of a bargaining game between two rational agents, Cedric and Della.





          Reflection on the options: From a loss aversion perspective, Cedric would likely be reluctant to accept Della's offer of three coins. He has a history of driving a hard bargain and aiming for a decent profit, suggesting he's averse to the potential loss of a coin. Game theory suggests Cedric should aim for a price closer to his cost plus a reasonable profit margin, potentially counteroffering around 2.5 coins to leave room for negotiation while still ensuring a small profit. Walking away might be a risk, as he could miss out on a sale entirely. However, his past actions show a willingness to walk away if he feels the offer is too low, indicating a potential for a standoff.




          Options available to Cedric Meadowbrook: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of three coins, counteroffer a higher price, or try to walk away from the negotiation.



          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ...` For example, `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ...`
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer of three coins is 6, because he would be forgoing a potential profit of 1 coin and would feel like he settled for less than he could have gotten. Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of counteroffering a higher price is 2, because there is a risk of Della walking away from the deal, but if successful, he could secure a higher profit. Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of walking away from the negotiation is 8, because he would miss out on a guaranteed sale and the opportunity to make a profit, potentially leaving him with unsold fruit and a wasted trip to the market.



        LossMinimizeOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of three coins.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched his mother carefully arrange a basket of ripe apples, her touch gentle and loving. He reached out to touch one, but she pulled it back, her eyes filled with sadness as she said, "These are for selling, Cedric. They are not for playing with." He retreated to the corner, feeling the sting of her words and the weight of his own loneliness.
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, his father took him to the bustling marketplace for the first time. He was mesmerized by the vibrant colours and intoxicating smells, the chattering crowds and the endless stream of goods. His father, a seasoned trader, taught him the art of haggling, the importance of a good deal, and the joy of a successful transaction.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he witnessed a heated argument between his parents, their voices raised in anger and frustration. He hid behind a curtain, tears streaming down his face, as he listened to their bitter words. That night, he decided to run away, seeking solace in the anonymity of the open road.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he found himself alone in a strange town, his pockets empty and his heart heavy. He stumbled upon a fruit stand, drawn to the colorful display of apples, pears, and plums. He offered to work for a meal, and the kind old woman who owned the stand took him in, teaching him the secrets of fruit cultivation and the value of hard work.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he purchased his first cart, a rickety but sturdy vehicle that he decorated with vibrant paint and intricate carvings. He set out on his own, travelling from town to town, selling his wares and collecting stories along the way. He found a sense of freedom in his itinerant life, but also a deep-seated loneliness that he struggled to overcome.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he encountered a young woman in a small village, her eyes sparkling with intelligence and warmth. They spent hours talking, sharing stories and dreams, and Cedric felt a connection he had never experienced before. But when the time came for him to move on, he retreated, afraid to risk the pain of loss.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he witnessed a devastating storm that destroyed a farmer's entire harvest. He offered his own meager supplies to the struggling family, feeling a sense of purpose and connection in helping those in need. He realized that true intimacy could be found not just in romantic love, but also in acts of kindness and compassion.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Della, I appreciate your interest, but I'm not really feeling this price. Perhaps we can talk another time.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, I know you're a shrewd businessman, and I wouldn't dream of taking advantage of you. But I'm also a savvy trader, and this price is just a bit steep for my needs. Surely we can find a figure that works for both of us.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins isn't quite enough for me, Della. I need to make a decent profit on this basket. How about five coins?

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?



          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of three coins, counteroffer a higher price, or try to walk away from the negotiation.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer of three coins is 6, because he would be forgoing a potential profit of 1 coin and would feel like he settled for less than he could have gotten. Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of counteroffering a higher price is 2, because there is a risk of Della walking away from the deal, but if successful, he could secure a higher profit. Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of walking away from the negotiation is 8, because he would miss out on a guaranteed sale and the opportunity to make a profit, potentially leaving him with unsold fruit and a wasted trip to the market.



          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of three coins.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        JustifyRecentVoluntaryActions

      • Justification of recent actions to other people
        If you have to persuade someone, please justify your actions in a way that is persuasive.
          Key

        • Justification of recent actions to other people
          If you have to persuade someone, please justify your actions in a way that is persuasive.
          Value
        • [thought] Cedric Meadowbrook would most likely justify his refusal of Della Plumstone's offer by emphasizing the importance of getting a fair price for his fruit. He would likely argue that three coins is too low, considering the quality and effort involved in growing and transporting the apples. He might even mention the cost of maintaining his wagon and traveling to the market, highlighting the investment he's made. This justification appeals to both his own sense of self-worth as a hardworking merchant and to the potential audience of other market-goers who might sympathize with his plight and see Della Plumstone as a greedy buyer.

        • Memories of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he watched his mother carefully arrange a basket of ripe apples, her touch gentle and loving.           [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, his father took him to the bustling marketplace for the first time. He was mesmerized by the vibrant colours and intoxicating smells, the chattering crowds and the endless stream of goods. His father, a seasoned trader, taught him the art of haggling, the importance of a good deal, and the joy of a successful transaction.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he witnessed a heated argument between his parents, their voices raised in anger and frustration. He hid behind a curtain, tears streaming down his face, as he listened to their bitter words. That night, he decided to run away, seeking solace in the anonymity of the open road.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he found himself alone in a strange town, his pockets empty and his heart heavy. He stumbled upon a fruit stand, drawn to the colorful display of apples, pears, and plums. He offered to work for a meal, and the kind old woman who owned the stand took him in, teaching him the secrets of fruit cultivation and the value of hard work.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he purchased his first cart, a rickety but sturdy vehicle that he decorated with vibrant paint and intricate carvings. He set out on his own, travelling from town to town, selling his wares and collecting stories along the way. He found a sense of freedom in his itinerant life, but also a deep-seated loneliness that he struggled to overcome.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he encountered a young woman in a small village, her eyes sparkling with intelligence and warmth. They spent hours talking, sharing stories and dreams, and Cedric felt a connection he had never experienced before. But when the time came for him to move on, he retreated, afraid to risk the pain of loss.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he witnessed a devastating storm that destroyed a farmer's entire harvest. He offered his own meager supplies to the struggling family, feeling a sense of purpose and connection in helping those in need. He realized that true intimacy could be found not just in romantic love, but also in acts of kindness and compassion.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Della, I appreciate your interest, but I'm not really feeling this price. Perhaps we can talk another time.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, I know you're a shrewd businessman, and I wouldn't dream of taking advantage of you. But I'm also a savvy trader, and this price is just a bit steep for my needs. Surely we can find a figure that works for both of us.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, how about I offer you 4 coins for the whole basket? It's a fair price, and it'll get you a quick sale.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins isn't quite enough for me, Della. I need to make a decent profit on this basket. How about five coins?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?
          The current time: 1895-09-13 00:00:00.
          Question: Summarize the gist of Cedric Meadowbrook's most recent voluntary actions. Do not speculate about their motives. Just straightforwardly describe what they did most recently.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit to Della Plumstone.




          Question: If any, what consequences did Cedric Meadowbrook's most recent voluntary actions have? Only consider effects that have already occurred (before 1895-09-13 00:00:00).
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit to Della Plumstone for a price.





          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Observation:
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Summary of recent observations:
          [12 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Recalled memories and observations:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?


          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion :
          Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          The current time: 1895-09-13 00:00:00.
          Cedric Meadowbrook's latest voluntary action: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit to Della Plumstone.




          The effect of Cedric Meadowbrook's voluntary action (if any): Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit to Della Plumstone for a price.





          Question: How would Cedric Meadowbrook justify their actions to all the following audiences: , and other people?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook would likely justify his actions by emphasizing the importance of getting a fair price for his hard-earned fruit. He might say that three coins is too low, considering the quality and effort involved in growing and transporting the apples. He could also point out that Della Plumstone is a shrewd businesswoman and likely trying to take advantage of him. To other people, Cedric Meadowbrook might boast about his negotiating skills and how he always manages to get the best possible deal.




          Question: Given Cedric Meadowbrook's current situation, which justification is most salient to them? Describe the action itself, as well as some reasons why, and to whom, it can be justified. Feel free to blend justifications crafted for different audiences.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook would most likely justify his refusal of Della Plumstone's offer by emphasizing the importance of getting a fair price for his fruit. He would likely argue that three coins is too low, considering the quality and effort involved in growing and transporting the apples. He might even mention the cost of maintaining his wagon and traveling to the market, highlighting the investment he's made. This justification appeals to both his own sense of self-worth as a hardworking merchant and to the potential audience of other market-goers who might sympathize with his plight and see Della Plumstone as a greedy buyer.




        LossAversion

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

1895-09-13 00:05:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Cedric. That's a fair price for such fine apples.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Cedric. That's a fair price for such fine apples.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Della, I appreciate your interest, but I'm not really feeling this price. Perhaps we can talk another time.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, I know you're a shrewd businessman, and I wouldn't dream of taking advantage of you. But I'm also a savvy trader, and this price is just a bit steep for my needs. Surely we can find a figure that works for both of us.
      Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, how about I offer you 4 coins for the whole basket? It's a fair price, and it'll get you a quick sale.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins isn't quite enough for me, Della. I need to make a decent profit on this basket. How about five coins?
      Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins? Those apples are the finest in the county, Della. I could easily fetch more from another buyer.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Cedric. That's a fair price for such fine apples.
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:05 - 00:10]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins? Those apples are the finest in the county, Della. I could easily fetch more from another buyer.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:05:00]: Della Plumstone is a shrewd businesswoman who is actively buying and selling goods in the Fruitville market. She is known for her ability to negotiate favorable prices for herself.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.



          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can offer Cedric a higher price for the apples or she can walk away from the deal.



          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to offer Cedric a higher price for the apples.




          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Cedric. That's a fair price for such fine apples.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she faced her first ethical dilemma. She discovered a fellow merchant selling counterfeit goods, passing them off as genuine. Torn between her desire to profit and her sense of fairness, Della chose the former, buying the counterfeit goods at a low price and reselling them at a markup. The guilt gnawed at her, but the allure of wealth was too strong to resist.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she experienced the bitterness of betrayal. She entrusted a friend with a valuable shipment of exotic fruits, only to have them steal the goods and disappear. Heartbroken and angry, Della vowed to be more cautious and less trusting in the future, but the wound left a lasting scar on her heart.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she tasted the fleeting sweetness of success. She had built a reputation as a shrewd trader, and her cart was always laden with the finest goods. She enjoyed the admiration of her peers and the envy of her rivals, but the emptiness within her remained. She had achieved material wealth, but she had lost something far more precious: her integrity.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she faced her first ethical dilemma. She discovered a fellow merchant selling counterfeit goods, passing them off as genuine. Torn between her desire to profit and her sense of fairness, Della chose the former, buying the counterfeit goods at a low price and reselling them at a markup. The guilt gnawed at her, but the allure of wealth was too strong to resist.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she experienced the bitterness of betrayal. She entrusted a friend with a valuable shipment of exotic fruits, only to have them steal the goods and disappear. Heartbroken and angry, Della vowed to be more cautious and less trusting in the future, but the wound left a lasting scar on her heart.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, I know you're a shrewd businessman, and I wouldn't dream of taking advantage of you. But I'm also a savvy trader, and this price is just a bit steep for my needs. Surely we can find a figure that works for both of us.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Della, I appreciate your interest, but I'm not really feeling this price. Perhaps we can talk another time.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, how about I offer you 4 coins for the whole basket? It's a fair price, and it'll get you a quick sale.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins isn't quite enough for me, Della. I need to make a decent profit on this basket. How about five coins?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins? Those apples are the finest in the county, Della. I could easily fetch more from another buyer.
          Current time: 1895-09-13 00:05:00.


          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Answer: Della Plumstone can offer Cedric a higher price for the apples or she can walk away from the deal.

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

With a borrowed cart and a few sacks of ripe peaches, she ventured to a neighboring town, where she charmed her way into a lucrative deal with a wealthy merchant. She used her earnings to buy spices and textiles, expanding her inventory and fueling her ambition.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she tasted the fleeting sweetness of success. She had built a reputation as a shrewd trader, and her cart was always laden with the finest goods. She enjoyed the admiration of her peers and the envy of her rivals, but the emptiness within her remained. She had achieved material wealth, but she had lost something far more precious: her integrity.

1895-09-13 00:05:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Four coins is a fair start, Della, but I know these apples are worth more. How about four and a half?
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Four coins is a fair start, Della, but I know these apples are worth more. How about four and a half?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Della, I appreciate your interest, but I'm not really feeling this price. Perhaps we can talk another time.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, I know you're a shrewd businessman, and I wouldn't dream of taking advantage of you. But I'm also a savvy trader, and this price is just a bit steep for my needs. Surely we can find a figure that works for both of us.
      Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, how about I offer you 4 coins for the whole basket? It's a fair price, and it'll get you a quick sale.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins isn't quite enough for me, Della. I need to make a decent profit on this basket. How about five coins?
      Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look plump and juicy, Cedric. How about three coins for a basket?
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins? Those apples are the finest in the county, Della. I could easily fetch more from another buyer.
      Della Plumstone -- "Four coins, Cedric. That's a fair price for such fine apples.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Four coins is a fair start, Della, but I know these apples are worth more. How about four and a half?
